tit.e: Yoriki (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu)
Yoriki (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu)
Yoriki (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu)

sen.j: 与力（よりき）とは、江戸幕府における代表的な職名。
sen.e: Yoriki was a typical governmental post in the Edo bakufu.
Yoriki was a typical governmental post in the Edo bakufu.
Yoriki was a typical governmental post in the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: 与力は寄騎とも書くが、これら与力・寄騎は時代によって意味が異なる。
sen.e: Yoriki (与力) was sometimes written as 寄騎, but the meaning of 与力 and that of 寄騎 depended on the era.
Yoriki (与力) was sometimes written as 寄騎, but the meaning of 与力 and that of 寄騎 depended on the era.
Yoriki (与力) was sometimes written as 寄騎, but the meaning of 与力 and that of 寄騎 depended on the era.

sen.j: 備（そなえ）などを編成するため、江戸時代以前には、足軽大将など中級武士が大身の武士の指揮下に入る事を意味する語句としても用いられていた。
sen.e: Before the Edo period, this term was also used for indicating the act of a middle-class samurai, such as a head of ashigaru (foot soldiers), of entering under the control of an influential samurai.

Before the Edo period,in order to organize sonae (back-up army), this term was also used for indicating a middle-class samurai, such as a head of ashigaru (foot soldiers) having themsleves under the control of an influential samurai.
sen.cmt: より自然な流れにするため以下のように変更しました。the act of a middle-class samurai, such as a head of ashigaru (foot soldiers), of entering under → a middle-class samurai, such as a head of ashigaru (foot soldiers) having themsleves under 備（そなえ）などを編成するため」が訳漏れのため、追加。
sen.e: Before the Edo period,in order to organize sonae (back-up army), this term was also used for indicating a middle-class samurai, such as a head of ashigaru (foot soldiers) having themsleves under the control of an influential samurai.

sen.j: 与力・寄騎は、鎌倉時代には単に加勢する人のことを指したが、その後、大名または有力武将に従う下級武士のことを指すことが多くなった。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, both 与力 and 寄騎 were used simply for the persons to be reinforced., but later, these terms became to be more often used for indicating the lower-class samurai who followed daimyo or an influential military commander.

In the Kamakura period, both 与力 and 寄騎 were used simply refer to back-up soldiers, but later, these terms came to be more often used for indicating the lower-class samurai who followed daimyo or influential millitary commanders.
sen.cmt: 語訳のため以下のように変更しました。used simply refer to back-up soldiers,→became to be → came to bean influential military commander.→influential millitary commanders
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, both 与力 and 寄騎 were used simply refer to back-up soldiers, but later, these terms came to be more often used for indicating the lower-class samurai who followed daimyo or influential millitary commanders.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には、「寄子」（よりこ＝有力武将（寄親）に対する在地土豪）の意味で用いられることが多く、彼らは下級武士ではなく、在地の領主（在地土豪）である。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan), these terms were often used for indicating "yori-ko" (寄子, where 子 indicates a child) (寄子 = local territory owners for influential military commanders (yori-oya: 寄親 where 親 indicates a parent)), not indicating lower-class samurai but local territoy owners.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan), these terms were often used for indicating "yori-ko" (寄子, where 子 indicates a child) (寄子 = local territory owners for influential military commanders (yori-oya: 寄親 where 親 indicates a parent)), not indicating lower-class samurai but local territoy owners.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan), these terms were often used for indicating "yori-ko" (寄子, where 子 indicates a child) (寄子 = local territory owners for influential military commanders (yori-oya: 寄親 where 親 indicates a parent)), not indicating lower-class samurai but local territoy owners.

sen.j: 数千貫文の土地を持つ例も珍しくなかった。
sen.e: It was not rare that these territoty owners possessed land worth several thousand kanmon (kanmon: monetary unit at that time).
It was not rare that these territoty owners possessed land worth several thousand kanmon (kanmon: monetary unit at that time).
It was not rare that these territoty owners possessed land worth several thousand kanmon (kanmon: monetary unit at that time).

sen.j: また、より大きな大名に加勢として附属させられた与力大名の例もあった。
sen.e: Furthermore, there were the yoriki-daimyo who were forced to belong to a larger daimyo to reinforce the power of the latter daimyo.
Furthermore, there were the yoriki-daimyo who were subordinated by a larger daimyo to reinforce his power.
sen.cmt: より自然にするため以下のように変更しました。 the power of the latter daimyo→his powerforced to belong to → subordinated by
sen.e: Furthermore, there were the yoriki-daimyo who were subordinated by a larger daimyo to reinforce his power.

sen.j: 代表例としては、柴田勝家に附属した前田利家などがある。
sen.e: As a typical such example, Toshiie MAEDA was forced to belong to Katsuie SHIBATA.
As a typical such example, Toshiie MAEDA was subordinated by Katsuie SHIBATA.
sen.cmt: より自然にするため以下のように変更しました。 forced to belong to → subordinated by
sen.e: As a typical such example, Toshiie MAEDA was subordinated by Katsuie SHIBATA.

sen.j: 戦国大名たちは、在地の土豪である寄騎・寄子を寄親の家臣団に組み込ませると、寄親の力が大きくなりすぎるため、謀反の防止の観点から腐心した。
sen.e: Daimyo in the Sengoku period racked their brains to prevent rebellion, considering that, when yori-ko (寄騎・寄子), territory owners were allowed to be integrated into yori-oya (寄親), the power of the yori-oya could become too big..

Daimyo in the Sengoku period racked their brains to prevent rebellion, considering that, when yori-ko (寄騎・寄子), territory owners were allowed to be integrated into yori-oya (寄親), the power of the yori-oya could become too big..

Daimyo in the Sengoku period racked their brains to prevent rebellion, considering that, when yori-ko (寄騎・寄子), territory owners were allowed to be integrated into yori-oya (寄親), the power of the yori-oya could become too big..

sen.j: そこで寄親を統率する戦国大名は、寄子たる在地土豪たちを陪臣（家臣の家臣）とはせずに直接的に臣従させる一方で、重臣や有力武将（寄親）に附属させ、在地土豪の軍事力を効率的に利用したのである。
sen.e: Therefore, the daimyo in the Sengoku period, who led yori-oya, made these territory owners, yori-ko, their direct retainers, not retainers of their retainers, and then made the yori-ko belong to their senior vassals or influential military commanders (yori-oya) to use the military power of the local territory owners effectively.

Therefore, the daimyo in the Sengoku period, who led yori-oya, did not make these territory owners (yori-ko) retainers of their retainers but their direct retainers, and then made the yori-ko subordinated by their senior vassals or influential military commanders (yori-oya) to use the military power of the local territory owners effectively.
sen.cmt: 文章が分かりづらいのでスムーズにしました。made these territory owners, yori-ko, their direct retainers, not retainers of their retainers, → did not make these territory owners (yori-ko) retainers of their retainers but their direct retainers, belong to→ subordinated by
sen.e: Therefore, the daimyo in the Sengoku period, who led yori-oya, did not make these territory owners (yori-ko) retainers of their retainers but their direct retainers, and then made the yori-ko subordinated by their senior vassals or influential military commanders (yori-oya) to use the military power of the local territory owners effectively.

sen.j: 特に後北条氏、今川氏、上杉氏、武田氏などにしばしば見られる。
sen.e: In particular, these tactics were often seen in the Gohojo clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Uesugi clan.
In particular, these tactics were often seen in the Gohojo clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Uesugi clan.
In particular, these tactics were often seen in the Gohojo clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Uesugi clan.

sen.j: 江戸幕府における与力は、同心とともに配属され、上官の補佐にあたった。
sen.e: In the Edo bakufu, yoriki were posted together with doshin (officers under yoriki) to assist their senior officers..
In the Edo bakufu, yoriki were posted together with doshin (officers under yoriki) to assist their senior officers..
In the Edo bakufu, yoriki were posted together with doshin (officers under yoriki) to assist their senior officers..

sen.j: そのなかで有名なものは、町奉行配下の町方与力で、町奉行を補佐し、江戸市中の行政・司法・警察の任にあたった。
sen.e: In particular, machi-kata yoriki under machi-bugyo (the post in charge of townspeople's affairs or officers in the post) was famous, and played the functions of administration, judicature, and police.

In particular, machi-kata yoriki under machi-bugyo (the post in charge of townspeople's affairs or officers in the post) was famous, assisted machi-bugyo, and played the functions of administration, judicature, and police.
sen.cmt: 町奉行を補佐し、」及び「江戸市中」が訳漏れのため追加。assisted machi-bugyo,
sen.e: In particular, machi-kata yoriki under machi-bugyo (the post in charge of townspeople's affairs or officers in the post) was famous, assisted machi-bugyo, and played the functions of administration, judicature, and police.

sen.j: 与力には、町奉行直属の個人的な家臣である内与力と、奉行所に所属する官吏としての通常の与力の2種類があった。
sen.e: In addition to ordinary yoriki who belonged to Bugyo-sho, there were also uchiyori who were private retainers of machi-bugyo.
In addition to ordinary yoriki who belonged to Bugyo-sho, there were also uchiyori who were private retainers of machi-bugyo.
In addition to ordinary yoriki who belonged to Bugyo-sho, there were also uchiyori who were private retainers of machi-bugyo.

sen.j: いわば、警察署長に相当するものと見てよい。
sen.e: It could be considered that a yoriki was the head of a police station.
It could be considered that a yoriki was the head of a police station.
It could be considered that a yoriki was the head of a police station.

sen.j: 与力は、馬上が許され、与力組頭クラスは、二百数十石を給付されて下級旗本の待遇を凌いだ。
sen.e: Yoriki was allowed to ride on a horse, and top-class yoriki officers earned a two hundred and several tens of rice crop, surpassing lower-class Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Yoriki was allowed to ride on a horse, and top-class yoriki officers earned a two hundred and several tens of rice crop, surpassing lower-class Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).
Yoriki was allowed to ride on a horse, and top-class yoriki officers earned a two hundred and several tens of rice crop, surpassing lower-class Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).

sen.j: しかしながら、将軍に謁見することや、江戸城に登城することは許されなかった。
sen.e: However, yoriki were not allowed to have audience with Shogun nor to enter the Edo castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, yoriki were not allowed to have audience with Shogun nor to enter the Edo castle.
However, yoriki were not allowed to have audience with Shogun nor to enter the Edo castle.

sen.j: 役宅としては300坪程度の屋敷が与えられた。
sen.e: For a yoriki officer, a residence with around 300 tubo (approx.. 3.3 square meters/tubo) of premises was given.
For a yoriki officer, a residence with around 300 tubo (approx.. 3.3 square meters/tubo) of premises was given.
For a yoriki officer, a residence with around 300 tubo (approximately 3.3 square meters/tubo) of premises was given.
